Department of Physics Kings Engineering College Sriperumbudur Chennai Tamil Nadu 602117 India Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) are proven to possess considerable resistance to environmental degradation such that they could not be entirely removed through the typical treatment processes. The consistent presence of these pollutants contributes to impending obnoxious health impacts that are concurrently inflicted on wildlife and human beings. In alignment of getting rid of these menaces, photocatalysis process has arrived as a tremendous remedy thereby the availability of clean and secure water could be ensured. In this review we focus on the potential progress in SnO2 nanostructures for enhancing the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, its current challenges and future perspectives. Keywords Nanostuctures Pollutants Photocatalysis Degradation Band gap Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past few years, the persisting climate change and the non-vailability of a standard water resource management continue to be perennial concerns that lead to water scarcity so that remedial measures such as the application of water reclamation and reuse grab tremendous attention, particularly among the environmentalists throughout the globe. Consistent decline of clean water becomes a daunting issue with which the growing economy worldwide would be at a critical stage with the increasing population in almost all countries [1]. Implementation of a standard system to achieve sustainable water development and management as well as wastewater reclamation and reuse, require powerful well-planned projects that have reliable solutions to do away with the prevailing water issues. However, the presence of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in treated water still arise concerns [2]. POPs that are bracketed with carbon-based chemical substances are continuously released into the environment such that they have resistance to environmental degradation. POPs are carcinogenic in nature and possess poor biodegradability thereby causing harmful effects for human beings and wildlife. To ensure the absence of POPs, the reclaimed water should be subjected to advanced treatment technologies. The familiar techniques that are involved in water treatment are such as adsorption, coagulation and membrane separation with which the removal of POPs from water streams can be accomplished to a certain extent [3], but these techniques only have the ability either to concentrate or change the recalcitrant organic pollutants into the constituent solid phase of water. Therefore, further treatments are unavoidable in order to treat the persistent secondary pollutants and to activate the process of regeneration of the adsorbents which require additional cost [4]. Because of this, recalcitrant organic pollutants with low biodegradability have been proposed to be eliminated through advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). AOP is a process wherein the assistance of Fenton's reagent, Hydrogen peroxide, Ozone, UV (Ultraviolet) light or a catalyst is involved for the in situ generation of highly effective chemical oxidants [5]. The hydroxyl radicals, that have generated, act as strong oxidants thereby they can oxidize recalcitrant organic compounds. AOPs can perform with an improved degradation rate and have the capacity to operate under ambient temperature and pressure. Moreover, they can have a major role in the reduction of the existing toxicity of organic compounds and in the process of mineralization of organic compounds so as to bring about green products [6]. Heterogeneous photocatalysis is one among the many AOPs which make use of a photocatalyst from the relevant semiconductor metal oxides [7]. Over the past few decades, TiO2 is the most studied semiconductor metal oxide because of its comparatively lower production cost and possessing a better chemical stability. TiO2 has ascertained itself as a commonly utilized to accomplish photocatalytic degradation of organic compounds like that of nitrogen containing organic compounds [8], saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) [9], aromatic hydrocarbons [10], non- biodegradable azo dyes [11], volatile organic compounds [12] and pesticides [13]. The presence of wide band gap energy i.e. 3.2 eV, as well as low quantum efficiency, highly restricts the photoresponse of TiO2 in the visible region [14]. In a similar manner, because of the wide band gap of SnO2 (3.6 eV), it could be an active photocatalyst in the UV region only. As it is known, only 4% of the solar spectrum is constituted by the UV region, while 45% of the spectrum accounts for the visible region. For enhancing the potential application of tin oxide to be an active photocatalyst, its response has to be optimum in the visible region. Hence, tailoring the band gap energy of SnO2 can be an option whereby it could be tuned as per the requirement. In order to reduce the band gap energy, there could be three potential ways wherein the modification of conduction band and valence band could be a possible option. According to the literature, there has been consistent progress made in enhancing the photocatalytic response in the visible region either by doping or by coupling SnO2 nanostructure with other potential nanostructures. By carrying out either doping or compositing, it is possible to accomplish a considerable amount of separation of electron – holes that could be achieved by constructing a heterojunction thereby changing the direction of electron transfer [15]. Even though AOPs show effective batement in recalcitrant organic matter, much more improvement is still to be attained. First, cost-effectiveness of AOPs is an important criterion that determines the reliable application of AOPs in water treatment plants. Moreover, costly chemicals and high consumption of electricity could result in heavy operational expenses such that limiting these factors would be a paramount task for the applicability of AOPs. Furthermore, the rate of degradation and the oxidation reaction very much rely on the making of hydroxyl radicals as well as regeneration of ions [16]. If the formation of hydroxyl radicals is not sufficient it results into the lowering of the efficiency of AOPs in batement of the existing recalcitrant organic pollutants. Over the past decades, many attempts have been made to augment the generation rate of hydroxyl radicals such that AOP treatments could be improved [17]. In addition to that, understanding the toxic effect of the intermediates and mineralization products emerging out of AOPs is of paramount importance. The process of nicotine removal by Fenton's reagent was initiated by Rodriguez et al. [18] so as to analyse the mineralization and the toxic nature of the intermediates that are generated in AOPs and they observed that even though 100% of the nicotine was removed, there was an incomplete mineralization wherein it was estimated the generated toxicity out of the intermediates which was found to be 15 times higher than the initial solution. In recent years, because of the advantages of the photocatalytic process, a good number of articles could be seen in the literature on synthesis and applications of photocatalyst. In order to make a feasible way out in bringing a reliable photocatalysis that can be put into practice on a large scale, a review should be carried out on the basis of well-defined applications with a suitable photocatalytic system that has various possible synthesis methods whereby SnO2 nanostructures could be obtained with the required dimension. The prime purpose of the current work is to investigate the mechanism behind tin oxide photocatalysts, to identify various synthesis process of SnO2 nanoparticles, to apply SnO2 in an effective way to the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, to find out the relevant techniques for enhancing SnO2 photodegradation efficiency, to list the factors affecting the photodegradation of organic pollutants in the aqueous dispersion of SnO2, to enable the surface modification of SnO2 thereby solving the future challenges and to seek the prospects of using SnO2 nanoparticles. 2 Photocatalytic mechanism of SnO2 nanoparticles SnO2 can be utilized as an n-type semiconductor since it has the value of 3.6 eV for band gap energy and 130 eV for excitation binding energy. Moreover, the absorption of UV light for this material is found to be promising and similar to that of TiO2, the nanoparticles of SnO2 have outstanding electrical, mechanical and optical properties.SnO2 exhibits good photocatalytic activity and has antibacterial and antifouling properties [19,20]. Letifi et al. [21] have reported that SnO2 is a promising candidate with exceptional and versatile properties which include strong chemical and physical interaction with absorbed species, considerably high transparency in the visible region, strong thermal stability in the air, low operating temperature, high chemical and mechanical stability and high electron mobility. Hence SnO2 is suggested to be used as heterogeneous photocatalysts. The heterogeneous photocatalytic steps involve: When SnO2 is photoinduced by a photon of energy ‘hν′ greater than or equal to the excitation energy ‘Eg’, electrons from the valence band jump to the empty conduction band such that e− - h+ pairs are produced as mentioned in eq. (1). As the e− - h+ pairs start migrating toward the surface of SnO2 they can involve in redox reactions as shown in eqs. (2), (3) and (4). Hydroxyl radicals are made because of the reaction of H+ with water while hydroxide ions and superoxide radicals are produced due to the reaction of electrons with oxygen. The produced superoxide radical anions further react with H+ and form hydrogen peroxide as shown in eq. (5). The reaction of hydrogen peroxide with superoxide radicals could pave the way for the formation of hydroxyl radicals as represented in eqs. (7), (8) and (9). The resulted in hydroxyl radicals are found to be excellent oxidizing agents such that they can attack the organic pollutants whereby they are adsorbed on the surface of SnO2 resulting in the rapid production of intermediate compounds. The resulting intermediate compounds will then be converted to green products like CO2, H2O and mineral acids as shown in eq. (11). Hence, the photodegradation mechanism of organic pollutants via redox reaction is summarized as below [22]. (1) SnO 2 → hν SnO 2 e − CB + h + VB (2) SnO 2 h + VB + H 2 O → SnO 2 + H + + OH · (3) SnO 2 h + VB + OH − → SnO 2 + OH · (4) SnO 2 e − CB + O 2 → SnO 2 + O 2 − · (5) O 2 − · + H + → HO 2 · (6) HO 2 · + HO 2 · → H 2 O 2 + O 2 (7) SnO 2 e − CB + H 2 O 2 → OH · + OH − (8) H 2 O 2 + O 2 · − → OH · + OH − + O 2 (9) H 2 O 2 + hν → 2OH · (10) Organic pollutants + OH · → Intermediates (11) Intermediates → CO 2 + H 2 O For the photocatalytic activity of SnO2 in the aqueous solution that is carried out under electromagnetic irradiation, OH· and H+ are the main active species and the electrons of the valence band are excited thereby move to the conduction band. Whereas, the holes occupy the valence band of SnO2 while a few of the holes react with H2O to form OH·. Consequently, the photodegradation of organic pollutants is carried out by the holes and OH·. The ability of photoactivity of a catalyst is governed by the creation of the number of photogenerated pairs of e− - h+. Moreover, because of the availability of the wide band gap energy, the optical absorption ability is modified which in turn affects the solar energy conversion performance of SnO2. On that count, it is imperative to enhance the optical properties of SnO2 such that the band gap energy would be minimized whereby the recombination of photogenerated e− - h+ pairs could be inhibited [23]. Fig. 5 shows the reaction mechanism scheme of SnO2 nanoparticles (SnO2 NPs) in the process of enabling efficient degradation of Methyl Orange dye. (See Figs. 1–4 .) 3 SnO2 nanostructured materials SnO2 nanostructures are significant for photocatalytic reactions since they can influence their use in various types of industries. A suitable SnO2 nanostructure could increase the process efficiency and improve photocatalyst recovery during the post-treatment phase. Several studies carried out earlier suggest that there have been a lot of attempts made to synthesis SnO2 of a variety of nanostructures thereby they can be classified as zero-dimensional (0D), one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) nanostructures (3D). In addition to that, quantum dots arrays, elongated arrays, planar arrays, and ordered structures are termed to be the subtypes of these nanostructures [25]. Nanorods, nanofibres, nanowires, nanotubes, and nanoneedles are bracketed to be 1D SnO2 arrays. Nanosheets and nanoflowers are the examples of SnO2 nanostructures that fall in the category of the respective 2D and 3D arrays [29]. Because of their excellent stability, mechanical durability, and bulk electron mobility, SnO2-based nanomaterials are being used in various developing applications which include photovoltaics, electrical, and photocatalytic processes. Bi doped nanosized SnO2 quantum dots are found to have outstanding practical application-oriented prospects due to their high efficiency and great stability [30]. 1 D SnO2 has widespread potential applications that are predominantly figure in electronics and gas sensing. Bang et al. [31] have performed experiments on the selectivity, stability and repeatability of SnO2 nanowires whereby they could authenticate that these nanowires have outstanding sensitivity and selectivity. Moreover, the making of branched nanowires for gas sensing applications is feasible as they can be fabricated in a simple way along with the flexibility in making the choice of sensing materials. It has been well-authenticated that the specific surface area of a photocatalyst has a high influence over its photocatalytic activity such that SnO2 nanosheets are identified to be potential materials for photocatalysis because they possess large specific surface area and polar faces [32]. Furthermore, the existing large specific surface area of SnO2 could facilitate more amount of absorption of impurities into its active surface thereby exposing more pollutants to hydroxyl radical attack. The chain reaction near the surface accelerates the degradation of pollutants, resulting in non-toxic products [33]. Wang et al. [34] have shown the ability of 3D nanoflowers which could exhibit a higher sensitivity in gases, acetone and ethanol in comparison with 1D and 2D structures since the nanoflowers possess much larger surface to volume ratio in comparison with the nanostructures of 1D and 2D. From this finding, it is quite clear that the performance of gas sensors has a higher dependency on the morphology of materials. In addition to this, SnO2 nanoflowers also have exceptional electrochemical performance such that they possess high specific capacity, good rate capability and improved cycle stability when compared to other SnO2 heterostructures [35]. In another study, Jin et al. [36] have reported that the 3D SnO2 nanostructures of flower like morphology display high response and selectivity to ppm level acetone, fast response and recovery time within 10s which demonstrate that they could be utilized to be probable contenders for detecting acetic acid. Chen et al. [37] fabricated nanoflower arrays of SnO2 by assembling a lot of nanosheets that are regular shaped whereby they are crosslinked so as to form the interior of the microflower. This technique combines the advantages of 2D and 3D SnO2 materials, resulting in a larger specific surface area. Structures of 3D nanoflowers have been branded as potentially promising materials because of their versatile usability wherein photocatalytic applications stand tall. Because of the presence of a large surface area, nanoparticles have an edge over the other materials such that they continue to be a preferred choice in solar photocatalysis whereby not only more pollutants can be easily absorbed but also a faster rate of degradation can be accomplished. In photocatalytic applications, it has also been observed that the large specific surface area and effective charge separation are significant [38]. 4 Synthesis of SnO2 nanostructure The synthesis of SnO2 nanostructures can be done in a variety of ways. There are two types of synthesis methods: solution-based and vapour-phase procedures. The band gap energies of semiconductor oxides are influenced by their size, crystal phase, and crystallinity. Based on a well-established model, researchers have hypothesized that the band gap energy of semiconductor compounds is inversely proportional to their size. This means that the efficiency of photocatalysis is determined by the synthesis conditions [39]. The solution-based approach could be preferred as it is one of the simplest and least energy-consuming fabrication methods for the synthesis of the SnO2 nanomaterial. It is fairly easy to control the morphology of the nanostructures using this synthesis approach by adjusting the experimental parameters such as solvent type, starting materials, and reaction conditions [40]. Furthermore, this approach allows the option of more precise control over the required sizes of the nanostructure. Solution-based routes to synthesize SnO2 nanostructures include hydrothermal [41], sol-gel [42], co-precipitation [43,44], microemulsion [45,46], solvothermal [47,48], electrochemical deposition process [49,50], microwave [51], polyol [52,53], wet chemical method [54], flux methods and electrospinning [55,56]. The sol-gel technique is identified to be the most appealing method for the synthesis of SnO2 nanostructure owing to its low production cost, high reliability, good repeatability, simplicity of the process, low process temperature, ease of control of physical characteristics and morphology of nanoparticles, and good compositional homogeneity and optical properties, [57]. For instance, Rahaman et al. synthesized Ni-doped SnO2 nanoparticles via this modified sol-gel technique which is identified to be in terms with the literature [58–60] wherein they made use of ethanol as the solvent such that the modified sol-gel technique employed to synthesize nanostructure could ensure good quality materials at a fairly lower fabrication cost. However, vapour phase approaches could also emerge such that fabrication of nanostructured materials has been accomplished and these processes include thermal evaporation [61], physical vapour deposition [62], metal-organic chemical vapour deposition (MOCVD) [63], chemical vapour deposition [64], plasma enhanced chemical vapour deposition (PECVD) [65,66],pulsed laser deposition [67] and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) [68]. Metal catalysts are used in several approaches to manage the growth of nanostructures. Without using any of the metal catalysts, Forleo et al. [69] were able to produce SnO2 nanorods possessing good crystallinity and optical quality. By adjusting the initial growth temperature of samples, they could modify the growth mechanism of SnO2, resulting in the creation of various nucleation layers of Sn adsorption. The selection of the SnO2 fabrication process is mostly determined by the desired nanostructure dimension. In the fabrication of 2D nanostructures, for example, the sol-gel technique and PECVD have been used. In comparison to the sol-gel method, the PECVD method has proven that comparatively lower temperatures are adequate to fabricate films [70]. Table 1 showcases the influence of various synthesis methods that have been employed for performing Tin Oxide characteristic studies. 5 Application of pure SnO2 in the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants Even though most of the applications with respect to the photodegradation of organic pollutants make use of doped-SnO2, a few of them have been described that show the potential prospects of pure SnO2 in the process of photocatalytic activity [37,82]. Despite the high efficiency of the process, UV rays have to be utilized so that the metal oxide can be activated because visible rays have insufficient energy in order to influence the production of e−- h+ pairs as pure SnO2 possesses wide band gap energy. The degradation of rhodamine B was studied using SnO2 nanocrystals prepared from amino-acid chelated tin salts. After 150 min of irradiation, the concentration of rhodamine B was reduced by 100%. [83]. On synthesizing nanocrystalline SnO2 particles from tin oxalate, an eggshell membrane was used to ensure rhodamine B degradation wherein similar results were achieved. After exposing the solution to UV radiation for one hour, the scientists found a 95% reduction in dye concentration [84]. Methylene blue, eosin Y, congo red, and violet 4 dyes were successfully oxidised using undoped SnO2 nanoparticles [85–88]. 6 Enhancing photocatalytic performance of SnO2 The practical utility of pure SnO2 is limited because of the high activation energy and the rapid recombination rate of photogenerated electrons and holes [89]. It is very essential to reduce the rate of recombination of the pair e−- h+ with which industrial applications can be facilitated such that photocatalytic activity can be improved [90]. Coupling SnO2with other semiconductors is a feasible option whereby different band gap energies could be possible for the metal oxide. Because of the lower activation energy and lower recombination rate of e− - h+ pairs, the doped material should have improved photocatalytic activity [91,92]. The next section discusses different ways for improving the characteristics of the metal oxide in order to ensure increased catalytic activity. 6.1 Metal /non- metal doping SnO2 has a tetragonal rutile structure [93] and it is a semiconductor possessing a high wide band gap of 3.6 eV at 300 K. SnO2 has registered to be a material of alluring attraction because of its flexibility with which it can be tailored in terms of electrical and microstructural properties thereby it could be a handy candidate for applications such as catalysts, electrochemical devices etc. as it possesses outstanding optical as well as electrical properties. In addition to that, SnO2 is known to have a high electron mobility (∼ 100–200 cm2V−1 s−1) that would enable a faster transport of photoexcited electrons. In comparison, the conduction band of SnO2 is more positive (0.5 V) in nature as against ZnO which could give room for to be a sink for the photogenerated electrons [94,95]. According to the literature, SnO2 can have the option of being combined with ZnO such that it would reduce the recombination of photogenerated e− and h+ because of its excellent physical as well as chemical properties [96–98]. The nanocomposites of SnO2 /ZnO that are synthesized out of the co-precipitation method employing the molar ratio Zn:Sn of 2:1 showcase comparatively higher activity of photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange (MO) as against the individual ZnO and SnO2 [89]. He et al. [99] have studied the novel p – type conductivity in the thin films of Mg-doped SnO2. The enhancement of the semiconducting nature of SnO2 is often hindered by the fluctuating nature of its conductivity. P-type thin films of high quality are very much essential in order to make SnO2-based optoelectronic devices. In recent times, p-type conductivity in SnO2 has been enriched by doping with various lower valence cations which act as acceptor dopants, such as Al [6,7], In [8], Ga [9,10], Sb [11] and Zn [12,13] such that holes are produced thereby the hole concentration is increased to enable the formation of p-type conductivity. Because of its excellent radiative stability, p-type SnO2 is an interesting prospect for a variety of applications. Jayapandi et al. [100] could accomplish in making a good quality CoNb dual-doped p-type SnO2 by employing the co-precipitation technique which stands to be critical for the synthesis of p-type SnO2 among the fabrication methods. Apart from that, co-doping has already been established to be a prominent path way through which modification of the optical properties of photocatalysts is very much possible because of the diverse nature of dopants that could be tried with different permutations and combinations. As previously stated, photocatalytic reactions are predominantly determined by bandgap energy as well as hydroxyl radicals. The low charge separation efficiency of SnO2 semiconductors as photocatalysts is their major drawback. Doping has therefore been used to tailor the required physical and chemical properties of SnO2 by the appropriate addition of dopants such as metals or non-metals such that it could cause the valence band energy of SnO2 to migrate upward thereby the bandgap energy is narrowed down to the UV – Vis region [15]. Non-metal dopants such as N, C, S, and F have been shown in recent research to modify the bandgap of SnO2 by substituting V0, resulting in more oxygen vacancy defects on the surface of nanoparticles. Because of the comparatively small in size, C, F, O, and N could undergo diffusion through the lattice interstices such that they attach to the atoms by the process of oxidation [101]. Carbon can be considered as a suitable candidate to be a non-metal dopant, especially for semiconductors because it possesses fairly high mechanical strength, good chemical resistance as well as special electronic properties [102]. Furthermore, doping can lead to a higher formation of OH radicals and, as a result, a higher efficiency of organic pollutant degradation can be achieved. This could be explained on the basis of the facts whereby the dopants can behave as electron hunters thereby preventing the recombination of e− – h+ pairs, thus, freeing the hole (H+) of the photocatalyst [103]. Compounds such as transition metals, rare earth metals, noble metals, and other metals are bound to have the required credential such that recently demonstrated experimental analyses have pointed out the benefits of modifying the morphology of SnO2 in photocatalytic as well as other applications. The trapping site of photo-induced charge carriers can be increased such that there would be a decreasing trend in the recombination rate of photo-induced electron-hole pairs thereby the process of metal doping of SnO2 could enhance the photoactivity of catalysts [104]. Metal dopants of Ce, Nd, Cu, and Al have been experimented in the process of dye degradation as well as gas sensing applications which is accomplished because of the lower bandgap energy of photocatalysts [80,105–107]. Wu et al. [106] reported that Ce-doped SnO2 prepared through a simple sol-gel method was potentially utilized in treating methyl orange via photocatalytic experiments. According to that research, the top most degradation efficiency was achieved at 7% for the Ce-doped SnO2 catalyst. On the other hand, it has been observed an unexpected increase in the electrical conductivity of SnO2 films when doped with Zinc. The observed optical data showcase the value of transmittance well over 80% in the visible region for all the developed films such that the doping process is proven to be efficient as the band gap is typically tuned [108]. Another study by Saadeddin et al. [109] reported that the simultaneously doped Zn and Sb in SnO2 ceramics result in increased electrical conductivity and high densities. Furthermore, the presence of Zn reduces the evaporation of Sb during the sintering process. Othmen et al. [110] reported that the addition of metal ions such as Fe3+ and Fe4+ results in a large tunable band gap of SnO2 NPs. It is reported that, after the inclusion of Fe, crystallinity of SnO2 improves while the addition of Fe4+ and Fe3+ ions play a tremendous part in enhancing the photocatalytic efficiency. Similarly, Yin et al. [111] has endeavoured to report the single source precursor route for the fabrication of heterogeneous nanomaterials wherein they have reported that when Ag/SnO2 heterogeneous material is employed as photocatalysts in the degradation of Conco red, its catalytic efficiency is 3-fold in comparison to the mixture of Ag and SnO2 powders. Toloman et al. [112] have come out with the result of the incorporation of excess of Co ions as the dopant so as to compensate the deficiency of oxygen in the SnO2 lattice. The supplement of Co ions in the SnO2 lattice results in maintaining the oxygen deficiency. Consequently, the visible emissions are decreased as a result of doping which specifies the lower recombination rate of photogenerated pairs of e− – h. In addition to that, it is known from the reports that Sn can be utilized to improve the electrical conductivity of SnO2 by means of doping inflicted on metals such as Co, Fe and Ni in such a way that no large lattice distortion is produced [113]. Chen et al. [114] reported that the doping of Ni could improve the probability of light harvesting thereby narrowing the band gaps of SnO2 quantum dots possessing particle size of ultra-small nature whereas the presence of large specific surface area could provide more reactive centres which are conducive for photocatalytic reactions. Even though metal dopants provide various advantages, non-metal dopants are lower in cost as against the metal dopants. Enhanced studies of higher order are required in order to explore the details of trends, performance and full-fledged characteristic nature of SnO2 on doping. As mentioned earlier, non-metal/metal doping has been frequently used to increase photocatalyst charge separation. In contrast, excess doping has been observed to be impacting a decrease in photodegradation efficiency [2]. Reddy et al. [115] reported the enhanced photocatalytic degradation activity of MO that was ensured by utilizing the Cr-doped SnO2 QDs (SnO2 quantum dots) as photocatalyst wherein different concentrations of Cr (0.01 mol%, 0.03 mol% and 0.05 mol% Cr-doped SnO2) were tried out. Eventually, they found out that the degradation efficiency could be improved gradually on increasing the Cr content whereby they could achieve higher efficiency of degradation for 0.03 mol% Cr doped SnO2 QDs (98.9%). Furthermore, their proposed interpretation suggests that a suitable amount of Cr ions which are present in the combination could efficiently capture the photoinduced electrons [80] thereby the amounts of surface hydroxyl radicals were increased in such a way that the photocatalytic degradation efficiency was proven to have improved for 0.03 mol% Cr doped SnO2. For 0.05 mol% of the dopant, the number of active sites that are essential for capturing photogenerated electrons are found to have decreased. Also, the presence of extra Cr ions could effectively shield the surface of the SnO2, which leads to the reduction of the photocatalyst active sites. Moreover, an increase in Cr concentration could act as recombination centres for electron-hole pairs such that the photocatalytic performance is reduced. Further, it has been proposed that when the photon energy is greater than or equal to the band gap energy of SnO2, an electron from the valence band (VB) will be stimulated to the conduction band and produce a hole in the valence band. Thereby, the produced holes in VB are trapped by H2O and OH− groups such that hydroxyl radicals are generated on the surface of SnO2 wherein the stimulated electrons are involved with the metal ions because of its differences in work function between SnO2 and metal ions whereby the recombination rate of photo-generated electrons and holes is reduced. Hydroxyl radicals and superoxide anions that are created by the photocatalytic procedure oxidize most of the organic dye compounds such that the oxidization continues until complete decomposition is attained. Fig. 8 a) and b) show the respective proposed mechanism of photocatalytic activity exhibited by Cr-doped SnO2 QDs and photocatalytic degradation curves of MO showcasing the outcome of without any photocatalyst and with the effects of SnO2 as well as Cr-doped SnO2 QDs. Table 3 showcases dopants of various categories blended with SnO2 nanostructures and the respective fabrication methods that were undertaken for the synthesis, which also include their photocatalytic applications. (See Fig. 14.) 6.2 SnO2 coupling with other semiconductors Coupling of two semiconductors is a technique wherein the semiconductor metal oxides are coupled in a combination such as MxOy/MezOt (where ‘M' and ‘Me’ denote the metal type while x, y, z and t are the oxidation states in these metal oxides) [116]. Nanocomposites are significant in certain applications in which photocatalysis, in particular, constitutes a major part because of their greater light absorption, better restriction of photoinduced e− – h+ pair recombination and increased charge separation [117]. The photocatalytic performance of SnO2 could be considerably enhanced if doping of the metal oxide is accomplished with either narrow or wide band gap semiconductors [118]. SnO2 semiconductors are widely utilized in combination with TiO2 semiconductors [119]. In the presence of doped SnO2, Vinodgopal and Kamat could successfully demonstrate the photodegradation of an azo dye. The researchers discovered that a 2:1 ratio of SnO2 to TiO2 is the most efficient combination for the degrading process [120]. Peng and colleagues fabricated SnO2/TiO2 nanotubes with various SnO2 concentrations and demonstrated that the composite material allowed for greater methylene blue absorption on the catalyst surface such that it resulted in increased metal oxide catalytic activity [121].The best photocatalytic activity could be obtained while a 5 wt% of SnO2 suspension of nanotubes was utilized. Moreover, Sang and colleagues observed similar results while making use of methylene blue as a pollutant [122]. In addition, a comparable SnO2/TiO2 composite material could exhibit good rhodamine B degradation performance [123]. Lin and Chiang [124] reported that the greater charge separation was owing to a prolonged charge carrier life due to inter-particle electron transfer that occurs between conduction bands of nanocomposites and as a result, a larger number of electrons are involved in the photodegradation mechanism. Stepwise energy level signature attribute to the improved properties of nanocomposites [125]. Nur et al. [126] observed that connecting two semiconductors with differing band gaps can result in a highly active photocatalysts. According to their reported mechanism, charge separation could be highly efficient because of the photoinduced electrons that move away from the photocatalyst. The activity of mesoporous SnO2 with a few dopants of ZnO (m-SnO2/ZnO) in the process of photocatalytic oxidation of rhodamine B occurring under UV illumination was examined. The photocatalytic activity of m-SnO2/ZnO was found to be more in comparison with m-ZnO [127]. ZnO has a considerably favourable effect on the photocatalytic activities of SnO2 even if it is at low concentrations. The construction of a ZnO/SnO2 heterojunction, which can promote the separation of electron-hole pairs, could pave the way for the increased activity of photocatalysis in the degradation of the dye which is promoted under UV light irradiation [128]. Wang, Xu, and colleagues synthesized a ternary mixture of ZnO, TiO2, as well as SnO2 and studied it for photocatalytic characteristics in methyl orange degradation. When compared to pure metal oxides, the mixture demonstrates increased activity. As the calcination temperature is exceeded 700 °C, the photocatalytic activity of the combination is reduced because of the generation of photo inactive ZnTiO4, Zn2SnO4, and Zn2Ti0.5 Sn0.5 O4. Moreover, When it is heated to a higher value of 1300 °C for an extensive time scale, all the photocatalytic properties of the combination experiences a gradual loss and completely goes off [129]. Gambhire could successfully report the preparation of the Cr2O3/SnO2 nanocomposite in 2013 [130] which is found to be effective in photocatalytic rhodamine B degradation. Furthermore, the photocatalytic activity of Fe2O3/SnO2 nanocomposite material was studied by Zhuang and colleagues such that a sample of acid blue 62 was exposed to visible light for 3 h during this study wherein the samples contributed by a 2:1 M ratio of iron to tin had the maximum photocatalytic activity. Also, it is observed when the particle size is reduced, the photocatalytic activity increases significantly [131]. When compared to pure Fe2O3, SnO2/Fe2O3 show enhanced photocatalytic performance which is achieved under the visible or UV irradiation [132]. SnO2/V2O5 nanowires exhibit better photocatalytic activity in the process of dye degradation occurring under the UV light as against pure V2O5 kept under the same condition [38]. The increased surface area of the heterostructure and the effective charge separation of SnO2/V2O5 are attributed to the improved photocatalytic performance. SnO2 has also been found to improve the photocatalytic activity of Cu2O which is undertaken for wastewater treatment [134]. Furthermore, a study reveals that CuO/TiO2/SnO2 catalysts have significantly more catalytic activity compared to CuO/TiO2 and CuO/SnO2 as catalysts [135]. Zhuang and colleagues synthesized CuO/SnO2 nanocomposite for the purpose of photodegradation of acid blue 62 carried out under xenon light irradiation. Because of the procured high surface area of the material from this process, the much higher photocatalytic activity could be obtained for the combination of the ratio of 1:1 mixture of CuO and SnO2 which was calcined at 500 °C for 1 h [136]. Zhang and colleagues synthesized SnS2/SnO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst that was activated by visible light. When compared to SnS2 or SnO2 nanoparticles, the system of physically coupled SnS2/SnO2 particles could demonstrate highly promising photocatalytic activity in the case of the decomposition of methyl orange. The considerably high catalytic activity can be elucidated by the matched band potentials of both the semiconductors such that the significantly narrower band gap of SnS2 causes electron transfer from the conduction band (CB) of SnS2 to SnO2 after the process of photoactivation [137]. Foletto synthesized CeO2/SnO2 nanocomposites and explored their potential nature of catalytic activity in the degradation process of an azo dye in the aqueous solution carried out under the visible light irradiation [138]. As and when the solution was exposed to sunlight for 60 min, the concentration of rhodamine B reduced by 98%, indicating that the combination of Cr2O3/SnO2 is a highly effective photocatalyst. The observed photocatalytic activity is known to be substantially higher than the activity of a normal P25 photocatalyst [130]. Zhang and colleagues described a new visible-light-driven SnS2/SnO2 nanocomposite that could be utilized as a catalyst that was used in the activity of oxidative degradation of methyl orange. In the combination of CdS possessing a narrow band gap of 2.4 eV with SnO2 possessing a band gap of 3.6 eV, there can be a beneficial activity possible because of the better e− - h+ couples' separation thereby extended lifetime of electrons and holes can be ensured such that the photocatalytic activity for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde occurring under the visible light irradiation is found to be higher than for pure semiconductors [139]. When BiOCl was combined with SnO2 nanoparticles via a two-step process, the observed photocatalytic activity, which gives rise to the degradation of rhodamine B, was increased under the visible light irradiation [140]. The degradation of methyl orange was previously investigated using nanosized coupled ZnO/SnO2 photocatalyst [141] such that according to the results, photodegradation of methyl orange is found to be decreasing with the increase in calcination temperature. When compared to samples calcined at 800, 900, and 1000o C, the samples calcined at 700 °C have outstanding photocatalytic activities that are because of the enhanced charge separation occurring through electron transformation from ZnO to SnO2 thereby small crystallite sizes and large surface areas are ensured whereas the samples calcined at 1000 °C have comparatively fewer efficiencies because of the formation of new intermediate phases of Zn2SnO4. As a result, the heterostructure of nanocomposites is considered to be an excellent approach to improve photocatalyst photoactivity. The most researched materials for photocatalytic processes include SnO2 combined with other semiconductors such that TiO2/SnO2, ZnO/SnO2, TiO2/SnO2/ZnO, and Co3O4/SnO2 have been extensively studied [142–145]. Paul et al. [146] experimented with the heterostructures of TiO2/SnO2 (keeping TiO2 on the top and SnO2 at the bottom) so as to establish the effect and verifying with the reverse order i.e. SnO2/TiO2 (keeping SnO2 on the top and TiO2 at the bottom) toward arriving at the efficiency of photocatalytic degradation of stearic acid and methylene blue under the influence of UV irradiation. Consequently, it was reported that TiO2/SnO2 display flake-like structures which could increase charge separation thereby ensuring a better degradation of pollutants under UV irradiation that could be achieved because of coupling heterostructures. The proposed reaction mechanism is given below: TiO 2 / SnO 2 → hν TiO 2 e − CB • • h + VB / SnO 2 e − CB • • h VB + SnO 2 e − CB + O 2 → SnO 2 + O − 2 TiO 2 h + VB + H 2 O → OH ∗ + H + OH ∗ + MB → degradation products Fig. 9 a) and b) show the photocatalytic efficiency and the related kinetics of Methylene Blue (MB) dye of the prepared samples under UV light irradiation, respectively. Schematic representation of photocatalytic reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 9 c). Finally, a biological application corresponding to SnO2-based nanocomposites is emphasised with a suitable example in this section. Pd photocatalytic antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli (E. coli), Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), Saccharomyces cerevisiae (S. cerevisiae), and Aspergillus aiger (A. aiger) spores was studied by Karakas and colleagues for the materials of SnO2 and TiO2 thin film samples. According to the observed data, TiO2 has a stronger antibacterial activity than SnO2. The addition of Pd, on the other hand, increases the activity of both the metal oxides. Moreover, the photocatalytic antimicrobial efficiency evaluated for different microorganisms and spores has come out with the result of decreasing trend in the order E. coli ˃ S. aureus ˃ S. cerevisiae ˃ A. aiger [147]. Das et al. [148] reported the experimental outcome of solar photocatalytic disinfection (SPCD) of a multidrug resistant (MDR) bacterium, Bacillus sp. CBEL – 1 while using Ag@SnO2@ZnO core-shell nanocomposites (NCs) as catalyst. Complete disinfection was ensured within 210 min while keeping the catalyst concentration at 500 mg/L and subjecting to NCs mediated photocatalytic disinfection (PCD) under solar irradiation. They identified H2O2 as the key reactive oxygen species (ROS) involved in the SPCD of targeted bacteria. Out of the observation, they reported an increase in the production of 4-HNE along with certain changes in fatty-acid profile of bacteria because of SPCD-induced oxidative stress which indicates the comprimisation of bacterial cell membranes. They could also observe an irreversible change in antibiotic resistance profile of the target bacteria after the implementation of SPCD thereby ensuring without any recovery even after 96 h of post-disinfection experiments. The coexisting traditional disinfectants and UV-250 nm were found to have a marginal impact on the resistance profile of the bacteria in comparison to SPCD. 6.3 Coupling of nanocarbon component to SnO2 Photocatalysts with heterojunctions can also improve the properties of SnO2 photocatalysts. According to Huang et al. [149], fabricating carbon-based heterojunction photocatalysts by coupling wide bandgap semiconductors not only promotes improved charge separation but also allows for good control over their thermodynamic properties. In the development of nanocomposites, carbon nanostructures play a promising role. In the past decades, the heterojunction of SnO2 with carbon nanotubes has been witnessed in the reports which are on track to confirm the improvement in the performance of nanocomposites in photocatalytic degradation [150], Supercapacitor applications [151], Lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries etc. [152]. Graphene has attracted interest in a variety of applications in recent years because of its outstanding electrical conductivity, high surface area, high electron mobility, and chemical stability in such a way that the trend continues with more and more advancements which include photocatalysis, gas sensing, photovoltaic devices, and fuel cells. Graphene is an array of single layer of carbon atoms in two dimensions wherein the thickness of the atom sized layer of sp2 carbon based nanomaterial are arranged in a hexagonal honeycomb lattice distribution. Single-layer graphenes contribute to a high specific area (2630 m2g−1), a high Young's modulus (1.0 terapascals), a high thermal conductivity (5000 Wm−1 g−1) and mobility charge carriers (200,000 cm2V−1 s−1) [153–156]. The existence of functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxide, carboxylic, and carbonyl groups is primarily responsible for these desirable properties. Singh et al. [157] developed SnO2/g-C3N4 photocatalysts via simple wet chemical method while using urea as a g- C3N4 precursor. Also, it has been further suggested that when the visible light is irradiated on SnO2/g-C3N4 catalyst, the photo-generated electron-hole pairs get separated for both the cases of g-C3N4 and SnO2 whereby the electrons in the conduction band of SnO2 recombine with the photo-generated holes of the valence band of g-C3N4. Therefore, the recombination of holes and electrons in the conduction band will be prevented (minimized). As a result of this, the electrons left behind in the conduction band of g-C3N4 effectively react with the molecular oxygen in order to form reactive superoxide radicals (O2 •-) thereby direct oxidization of the dyes is enabled. Also, O2 •- reacts with H2O and further reduce to form hydroxyl radicals (HO−). In addition to that, the photo-generated holes (h+) in the valence band of SnO2 start reacting with a water molecule and HO− such that HO• radicals are produced. As the HO• and O2 •- radicals are powerful oxidative species they can efficiently degrade the contaminant dye molecules thereby harmless and safer end products such as CO2 and H2O are ensured. Moreover, they investigated the impact of different mass ratios (SnO2: g-C3N4 = 1–5: 5–1) thereby choosing the photocatalytic degradation process for the treatment of synthetic wastewater which had contained organic and textile dyes namely, Rhodamine B (RhB) and Remazol Red X-3BS (RbX). Consequently, they observed that the synthesized photocatalysts exhibited excellent degradation efficiency for the pollutants because of the derived synergistic effect of g- C3N4 and SnO2. Kinetic studies undertaken on RhB and RbX degradation could reveal the highest rate constant for the SnO2/g-C3N4–1:1 catalyst, which is found to be much higher than that of pure g-C3N4. Fig. 11 a) and b) display the impact obtained for different mass ratios of SnO2/g-C3N4 photocatalysts on the degradation of RhB and RbX, respectively while Fig. 11 c) shows the photocatalytic degradation mechanism of SnO2/g-C3N4 photocatalyst. The electrical conductivity of graphene oxide (GO) is perturbed by oxidation, resulting in to be an excellent electrical insulator [158,159]. By adjusting the pH of GO to an appropriate value in solution and allowing it to undergo thermal treatment, GO can be converted into reduced – graphene oxide (rGO). Because of the graphene encapsulation, there are an enhancement in specific surface area, and electrical transport capabilities and the recent studies have indicated that the heterostructure of SnO2/GO has better charge separation ability thereby confirming the applicability of such SnO2/rGO hybrids for photocatalytic applications [110,160]. Dutta et al. [161] synthesized reduced graphene oxide nanocomposites with SnO2 quantum dots and reported that QDs - rGO is an excellent candidate for removing positively charged organic dyes, harmful heavy metal ions, and microbial pathogens from waste water. According to a report, an increase in organic pollutant adsorption is likely owing to π – π conjugation occurring between the organic pollutants and the sp2 regions of rGO [162]. To achieve optimum removal efficiency, more diversified research on graphene adsorption behaviour under different situations is required. The photocatalytic decomposition of organic pollutants should improve when SnO2 is combined with rGO. Nevertheless, loading of rGO over the optimum level contribute to the reduced degrading efficiency which might be due to excessive photo-absorbing and scattering [163]. The relation between SnCl4.5H2O dosage and photocatalytic activity of SnO2/rGO –HM (HM- Hydrophilic Macroporous) composite has been experimented by Hong et al. [164] SnO2/rGO- HM photocatalyst possesses a good photocatalytic activity that is better than the regular SnO2/rGO, pure SnO2, and commercial TiO2 photocatalyst when utilized to degrade Rhodamine B and Methylene blue (p25). The prevailing hydrophilicity, high specific area of the composite and uniform dispersion of SnO2 nanoparticles over rGO sheets are all the contributing factors in the superior photodegradation performance. Shyamala et al. [165] anchored 2D-rGO on the surface of SnO2 with the intension of extending the absorption to the Visible region. The proposed reaction steps that are involved in the photocatalytic degradation process which happens under UV light are as follows: SnO 2 + hν → SnO 2 e − CB + h + VB photo − generated charge carriers SnO 2 e CB − + graphene → SnO 2 + graphene e − transfer of e − to graphene 2D network Graphene e − + O 2 → graphene + O 2 e − capture by oxygen molecule SnO 2 h + VB + OH − → SnO 2 + OH generation of OH radical by VB holes OH + pollutants → Degradation products Photodegradation The proposed excitation processes involved under the irradiation of solar light are presented below: RhB + hν → RhB + Photoexcitation of RhB molecule Graphene + hν → graphene ∗ Photoexcitation in graphene network RhB ∗ + SnO 2 / RGO – SnO 2 → SnO 2 / RGO – SnO 2 e − CB + RhB + Photosensitization graphene ∗ → e − O 2 / SnO 2 / RGO − SnO 2 + graphene Photosensitization The photoresponse of rGO-SnO2 was observed to be excellent under both the UV and Visible light irradiation. They accounted that the overall attained efficiency of rGO-SnO2 could be attributed to the enhanced absorption enabled by both rGO and SnO2 which could effectively extend light absorption in the visible region thereby ensuring efficient charge separation and excellent charge transport. Furthermore, they reported that rGO-SnO2 composite could attract greater interest because of the interesting fact of usual properties of metal oxide could be combined with the unusual properties of rGO. Fig. 12 a) shows UV–Visible absorption spectra of the RhB solution recorded during the process of degradation with rGO-SnO2 photocatalyst under the UV light irradiation and b) shows the plot of C/Co versus time in min under the irradiation of the UV light and solar light. Fig. 13 a and b display the graphical representation of the process of vectorial charge transfer in the rGO-SnO2 sample under the illumination of UV light and solar light, respectively. Table 2 shows the rate constant (k) and % of RhB degraded under the illumination of UV and solar light. 7 Factors influencing the photodegradation of organic pollutants in the aqueous dispersion of SnO2 As the previous section could accommodate the details on the effect of various dopants in photocatalytic activity, the upcoming section could contain the external factors that influence the photodegradation of SnO2. 7.1 Effect of pH of the solution in use The total effectiveness of photocatalytic degradation of aromatic dyes greatly depends on the pH of the polluted solution. The pH determines not only the oxidation potential of the pollutant but also the charge of the pollutant and/or the nature of the surface of the photocatalyst. It is very much required that the reaction carried out should be within the permissible stability range of the photocatalyst. Lower pH ranges have been proven to be advantageous to the rate of breakdown of organic contaminants in several circumstances [190]. Researchers working in this field have consistently highlighted enhanced phenol decomposition under slightly acidic circumstances [191]. A slightly acidic nature of the pH range improves the attraction of pollutants to the surface of the photocatalyst and ensures faster breakdown rates [59]. However, if the pH of the reaction mixture falls lower than a particular level, the reaction rate slows dramatically. Malik et al. [192] prepared tin oxide nanoflowers through a facile hydrothermal technique. They investigated the influence of varied pH in the photocatalytic degradation of Rose Bengal (RB) dye under the visible light irradiation and found that on increasing the pH, the hydroxyl ion concentration in the reaction system increases which causes them to react with more holes thereby generating more holes and hydroxyl radicals. The degradation efficiency of RB was inhibited when the pH was kept above 9 because of the phenomenon of hydroxyl desorption with the dye molecules on the surface of the catalyst. Fig. 15 a) shows the photocatalytic performance of SnO2 nanoflowers against RB dye for various values of pH with a fixed photocatalyst dose (0.2 g/L). 7.2 Effect of catalyst concentration The quantity of catalyst that is required for any large-scale application is critical in determining the overall efficiency of the process [193]. As a result, numerous groups have weighed in on the optimal concentration of SnO2-based photocatalysts for organic pollutant degradation. According to Ismat-Shah and coworkers, the photocatalytic degradation rate is found to be initially increasing with the increase in catalyst concentration whereas gradually decreasing after the optimum catalyst loading is reached [194,195]. The overall increase observed in the active surface area of the catalyst in suspension could provide the reason behind the initial increase in photocatalytic activity. However, as the catalyst concentration rises, turbidity rises as well, thereby light transmission in the suspension decreases [196]. As a result, increasing the catalyst loading would ensure the prevention of light from passing through the solution whereas only photocatalytically active catalyst particles left closer to the surface may contribute [197]. Malik et al. [192] investigated the effect of varying the catalyst concentration in the photocatalytic degradation of Rose Bengal (RB) dye maintained at pH 9 under the visible light irradiation while using SnO2 as the photocatalyst whereby they could obtain the best degradation efficiency for 0.6 g/L SnO2 concentration. Moreover, they reported that the active sites and density of particles in the illumination area hike with the increase in catalyst concentration of the photogeneration process. But, at higher catalyst loading (> 0.6 g/L), the degradation efficiency started decreasing due to the agglomeration of SnO2 nanoparticles in the reaction system. Also, their report suggests that the trend of a decrease in radiation penetration and the increase of radiation scattering progressively occur at the higher level of catalyst loading. Fig. 15 b) portrays the photocatalytic performance of SnO2 nanoflowers against RB dye for various values of catalyst concentration at a fixed pH 9. 7.3 Effect of dye concentration With the increasing pollutant concentrations, photodegradation efficiency is identified to be decreasing gradually [198]. One of the reasons is that organic dyes absorb light, reducing the amount of radiation that is available in order to activate catalyst nanoparticles. Furthermore, when all active sites on the catalyst's surface are occupied, the reaction rate slows down such that additional pollutant molecules are destroyed only when the active sites become accessible again [199]. The photocatalytic degradation activity of phenol has been scrutinized by Al-Hamdi et al. at various initial concentrations ranging between 5 ppm and 50 ppm. The results show that phenol degraded quickly at the concentration of 10 ppm but the rate of degradation slowed marginally while the initial concentration had started increasing in excess of 15 ppm [200]. Kuzhalosai et al. [201] synthesized SnO2 loaded ZnO by precipitation-decomposition method such that they investigated the effect of dye concentration on the photocatalytic degradation of Acid Orange 10 (AO 10) dye under the UV-A light irradiation. They observed that as the dye concentration was increased from 1 х 10−4 M to 9 х 10−4 M, the rate constant decreased from 0.1203 to 0.0197 min−1. Fig. 16 shows the effect of dye concentration in the degradation of AO 10 dye while maintaining all the other parameters constant. 7.4 Effect of light intensity and wavelength The activation of catalyst depends on the irradiation of light with specific wavelength and intensity [202]. On increasing the intensity of light as well as energy more than that of the activation threshold, the effectiveness of the photocatalytic system naturally increases [203–206]. Even in the absence of adequate photocatalysts, high-intensity and high-energy light can produce radicals such as OH•. While a radiation with high magnitude of intensity and wavelength is exposed to a sample, the mechanism involved in for the formation of reactive radicals is a dependent factor with which further rate of increase is decided [207–210]. Aside from the light intensity, the energy of each of the photons is extremely important such that excitation could be possible only when photons of adequate energy make an interaction on the surface of the photocatalyst due to energy quantization. Different light sources are required which depends on the band gap of the photocatalyst. Band gaps of 3.1 to 3.9 eV require light with wavelengths of 315–400 nm such that excitation is ensured. On the other hand, band gaps ranging between 3.9 and 4.4 eV are in need of light of wavelengths ranging from 280 to 315 nm. If the band gap exceeds the numbers as aforementioned, much more energy (3.1 to 3.94 eV) is required or otherwise the operation becomes unfeasible [211,212]. The band gap of SnO2 with adequate dopants is typically less than 3.1 eV such that it allows visible light activation of the photocatalyst thereby ensuring extensive applicability of the semiconductor. To improve overall efficiency, light sources that generate light at multiple wavelengths should be employed to excite catalysts of broad energy bands [213]. Luque et al. [24] carried out the process of photocatalytic degradation of MO in the presence of SnO2 photocatalyst under the UV as well as solar irradiation. They found that 4% Citrus х Paradisi extract added to SnO2 NPs could degrade 100% of the MO-contaminated solution in 180 min under the solar irradiation. The NPs with the extract percentages of 1% and 2% exhibited significantly lower degradations of meagre values of 17 and 29%, respectively. On the other hand, when placed the solutions containing the prepared catalyst and dye under the UV radiation, the SnO2 NPs (4%) caused the removal of the contaminant for a time span of only 20 min of exposure. The UV-MO-SnO2 (1%) and UV-MO-SnO2 (2%) samples could degrade 52 and 72%, respectively at the exposure of 180 min. Fig. 17 a) and b) display the photocatalytic degradation of MO using SnO2 NPs under the visible light irradiation and UV irradiation, respectively. 7.5 Effect of crystallinity and surface area The crystallinity of the photocatalyst has a significant impact on its overall efficiency [214]. Heterogeneous catalysts possessing large surface areas are more suitable since they could give room for more reactant absorption. The process of doping of SnO2 alters and modifies the crystal structure whereby it results in a decline in crystal size whereas an increase in active surface area. Furthermore, doping SnO2 serves a dual effect in such a way that it changes the electrical characteristics of the semiconductor by narrowing the band gap while also increasing the contact area between the catalyst and the pollutant. When several metals of differing amounts were doped into a sample of SnO2, the photocatalyst surface area increased in all situations, resulting in improved catalytic activity. Up to a specific threshold, which varied for each pollutant, this constant increase was observed (on condition that it depends on the charge, the size of the ion, and all other relevant factors) [215–217]. Kar et al. [218] explored the variation of photocatalytic properties of SnO2 by altering its morphology. NPs, nanowedges (NWs) and nanospheres (NSs) of SnO2 had been synthesized and tested for the influence of morphology and agglomeration on photocatalytic properties by choosing MB as the model dye. They could come up with the findings that 98% of MB was degraded in the presence of SnO2 NPs after 120 min while the degradations were 58% and 33% for SnO2 NWs and NSs, respectively. Subsequently, they could authenticate SnO2 NPs as the most effective catalyst tested by virtue of their high surface area thereby resulting in a photocatalytic activity of 1.16 х 10−4 mol dm−3 s−1 m−2. Table 4 shows the photocatalytic activity, surface area and activity per unit surface area of the prepared samples. Reprinted with permission from [218], Copyright (2019), Elsevier. 8 Shape control and surface modification of SnO2 8.1 Crystal growth and shape control Various approaches have been employed to change the morphology, size, and growth of SnO2 in order to improve photoactivity. Variations in the surface lattice plane and surface area of photocatalysts have been proven to be affecting photocatalytic activity [219]. For example, stabilizing agents have been made use of quite efficiently to modify the structure of SnO2 nanoparticles. In a similar experiment, Vijayalakshmi et al. [220] investigated the impact of various stabilizing agents as that of poly vinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), zeroth generation triazolyl glycodendrimer and zeroth generation triazolyl chalcone dendrimer on the structural properties of Ag@SnO2 core shell nanoparticles thereby could come up with the report of a decrease in bandgap energy which is the effect of stabilizer on the samples. In a similar way, the morphology of SnO2 could be modified by manoeuvring the molar ratios of the precursors that are to be used [221]. Talebian et al. [222] have experimented with the impact of hydrothermal temperature and treatment time on the resultant morphology of the SnO2 nanoparticles. They have investigated that the SnO2 flower shaped catalysis which have showcased higher activity in comparison with the others' suggestion such that the morphology of the catalysts put forth a considerable influence on their performance. Sarabadani et al. [223] suggested that a few of alkaline chlorides acting as precursors contribute prominent part in controlling the morphology of SnO2 nanostructures. The precursor concentration, precipitant agent, and reaction temperature are regarded as the influential crucial factors with which there could be an impact on the SnO2 photocatalyst that is prepared utilizing the precipitation method in the SnO2 preparation processes [224,225]. Galvez et al. [226] investigated the variation of photocatalytic degradation of the MB under the influence of the UV irradiation of the biosynthesized SnO2 NPs by altering the percentage of Lycopersicon esculentum peel extract. The proposed degradation process is categorised into three stages 1) adsorption, 2) generation of oxidative species and 3) MB degradation. It is reported that the SnO2 nanoparticles exhibit an excellent MB molecular adsorption capacity (Fig. 20 ) because of the ≠ − ≠ interactions that occur between the MB and the aromatic rings present in the tomato extract. The adsorption could enrich the concentration of MB molecules over the extract thereby placing the MB closer to the photocatalytic surface of the SnO2 which is found to be a pre-requisite to enhance photocatalytic activity (Fig. 21 a). The process of generation of oxidative species could be initiated with the irradiation of the SnO2 with UV light whereby electrons are generated in the conduction band and holes in the valence band (known as the photo-excitation process), which in turn generates electron-hole pairs. The generated electrons interact with the dissolved oxygen (O2) thereby photo-oxidization is enforced such that superoxide radicals (O2 ∞) are produced while the holes photo reduce the water molecules (H2O) thereby generating hydroxyl radicals (OH∞). Both (O2 ∞ and OH∞) are highly oxidizing species (Fig. 21b). Eventually, the process of MB degradation starts when the O2 ∞ and OH∞ radicals degrade the MB molecules such that H2O and carbon dioxide (CO2) are produced as by-products of the reaction (Fig. 21 c). As shown in Fig. 20, when the percentage of Lycopersicon esculentum peel extract is increased, MB adsorption increases and according to the report, it might be because of the extract that is functionalized on the surface of SnO2, which has an affinity for the MB molecules thereby producing an increase in the photodegradation efficiency. After 120 min of irradiation with the UV light, the samples achieved 67%, 85% and 99% degradation for the 1%, 2% and 4% samples, respectively. The sample with the highest photocatalytic performance was observed for the sample with 4% extract which might be due to the large amount of MB molecules absorbed (60%) and it has the smallest average size. Fig. 19 showcases the TEM and size distribution of the different SnO2 samples along with their respective size averages. Schematic representation of the photocatalytic process of SnO2 nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 21. The chemical reactions for SnO2 synthesis that is carried out through chemical approach are as follows: 3Sn 2 + + 4H 2 O ⇌ Sn 3 OH 4 2 + + 4H + 2 Sn 3 OH 4 2 + + 4OH − → Sn 6 O 4 OH 4 + 4H 2 O The calcinations process is a dehydration reaction wherein the occurring oxidation results into the product of SnO2 nanoparticles [227], such that the SnO to SnO2 reaction is observed at temperatures approximately above 400 °C [224,228] as follows. Sn 6 O 4 OH 4 → 6SnO + 2H 2 O 2SnO + O 2 → 2SnO 2 Intermediate concentrations of OH−, on the other hand, have resulted in to both uniform as well as anisotrophic growth that contribute to the uniformity in the shape of nanoparticles and nanorod nanostructures. A recent study has established a link between various precursor concentrations and the yield of SnO2. The maximum yield as per the studies using sodium hydroxide as the precipitant is 92.95% whereas, the best yield of the experiments using ammonia as the precipitant is 97.58%. As the precursor concentration was increased, the SnO2 yield flourished until it reached equilibrium at 0.05 M. Furthermore, when the concentration of the precursor was observed to be excessively high, precipitation could occur even without the addition of a proper precipitant. The stability of the precipitation process was influenced by the experimental condition of high concentration precursors, therefore a precursor concentration of 0.05 M is to be utilized in order to fulfil the experimental follow-up condition for the synthesis of photocatalyst materials [229]. The photocatalytic activity of SnO2 crystallites has been closely correlated with their respective band gap energy. It has been observed in the previous research [230] that the band gap energy of the smallest particles is smaller than that of the bulk SnO2 but increases with nanoparticle size. Karmaoui and co-workers observed unanticipated changes in band gap energy ‘Eg’ with respect to the NP size that is because of the internal strain parameters developed within the NPs which lead to an increase in screw dislocation densities occurring at higher temperatures since the particles become larger in size. They reported that the internal strains which have been developed could be correlated to the presence of organic ligands attached to the growing NP surfaces derived from the synthesis reaction and they have suggested the sol-gel method as the simple, low-cost synthetic methods which have the potential in leading to new possibilities for tailoring the ‘Eg’ of SnO2 nanomaterials as a function of NP size, surface decoration, and the presence or relaxation of interview mechanical strains. By undertaking an approach similar to the one as above mentioned can provide further scope of the tuning of the electronic properties. adsorption, b) generation of oxidative species and (c) MB degradation.
