Surface modification can be the best option in order to ensure better dispersion that could be achieved by preventing the agglomeration of SnO2. Moreover, the surface modification has also been implemented to tune the ultraviolet and visible light luminescence, semi conductivity, mechanical enhancement. In contrast, the substrate material could make an impact with which it can decrease the agglomeration thereby enhancing the physical - chemical properties of the nanoparticles, such as reactivity and processability. By taking into account of the surface modification with respect to SnO2 nanoparticles, it is probable to attain excellent properties and potential applications in the fields of gas sensing and photocatalysis [232,233]. Chemical treatment modifies the surface of nanoparticles by using coupling agents (e.g., trimethoxyvinyl silane and oleic acid). In comparison to bare SnO2 nanoparticles, modified SnO2 synthesized by Xiong et al. [234] using grafting polymerization has shown a long-term in terms of durability and improved dispersion in organic matrix. Ligand molecules are also commonly used as capping agents in the coating process to avoid nanoparticle agglomeration and control growth. Before recombination can happen, the ligand layer acts as an insulator, blocking charge transport between neighbouring nanoparticles [235]. Recently, it has been shown that coating metal oxide nanoparticles with polymeric ligands work better in comparison with the monomeric ligands in the case of stability. This is because of the existence of steric and electrostatic forces in polymeric ligands that has been employed to stabilise the metal oxide, whereas only electrostatic repulsive forces could contribute to metal oxide stabilisation in the latter [236]. Although the coating approach improves the dispersion of nanoparticles in the matrix, it also has the potential to obstruct photocatalysis [237]. Ligand exchange may be a better option for simultaneously stabilizing and improving the performance of nanoparticles. In this sense, Kango et al. [238] suggested that ligand molecules be replaced with more suited ligands so as to improve electron transport by reducing separation effects [222]. By adjusting the molar ratio of Sn2+ and OH− ions, flower-like SnO2 structures were successfully fabricated. Excess OH− has been connected to the development of the Sn3 (OH)4 2+ complex as reflected in previous studies. The production of nanosheet arrays from particles was favoured by subsequent dehydration of the Sn3 (OH)4 2+ complex. It was observed that adding stabilisers causes some desirable chemical moieties to adhere to the nanoparticle surface, preventing them from growing and eventually yielding a preferred size [239,240]. Polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) has received increasing attention among the numerous surfactants since it is water soluble, biocompatible, and environmentally friendly [241]. Toloman et al. [242] used SnO2 nanoparticles in the presence of PVP surfactant to make SnO2/TiO2 nanocomposite with enhanced Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) production, which was then capped with TiO2. The surface area of SnO2/TiO2 nanocomposites increases as the initial PVP content increases due to interface adsorbed PVP moieties, however, pore distributions are drastically modified as the polymer content increases. The ionisation potential of the TiO2 outer shell is also modified by interface adsorbed molecules. As a result, the band alignment that is present between the two components is rearranged, and an excited electron at the bottom of TiO2 CB has an energy equivalent to or greater than the Fermi level in SnO2. The characterization results revealed that band gap of TiO2 has a large number of localised states that can spread across the entire space of the forbidden gap. By implementing the process of trapping the electrons in the CB of SnO2, the combination of band rearrangement and band gap localised states could contribute in reducing the efficacy of direct recombination of light produced by e− – h+ pairs. The photogenerated holes are more likely to evolve to the surfaces of TiO2 crystallites and react with the aqueous solution because of this trapping. They interact with localised Ti3+ states and create ·OH species in the aqueous phase. As a result of this chain of induced changes, a sample with low PVP concentration has significantly improved photocatalytic activity. Suthakaran et al. [243] conducted a few photocatalytic experiments for the degradation of Methyl Violet (MV) by the irradiation process in the presence of three different catalyst (bare SnO2, SHMP (Sodium hexametaphosphate) assisted SnO2 and Zn doped SnO2) to show as to how surfactants assisted SnO2 photocatalyst could affect the efficiency of photocatalysis. From Fig. 22 , it is clear that the photocatalytic performance of surfactant assisted samples is much better in comparison to the bare SnO2 sample. 9 Reusability of SnO2 based photocatalyst Estimating the potential prospects of reusability of the photocatalysts is one of the prominent requirements such that the investigation of the applicability of novel nanomaterials as photocatalysts has to be consistently witnessed in progressive research. Of late, the documentation of the reusability of potential photocatalysts is not considered to the level of the required convention. Moreover, most of the previous studies that are found in the literature lack investigations of this nature. However, exceptional reusability results are observed for the semiconductor metal oxides such as SnO2, ZnO etc. Shivangi et al. [244] have carried out the photocatalytic degradation of crystal violet dye using Ni/NiO/SnO2 photocatalyst thereby 94% degradation efficiency could be obtained in 40 min. In addition to that, they have conducted regeneration experiments to check the feasible nature of the reusability of the nanomaterial. After each of the experiments, the respective nanomaterials have been exposed to the sunlight for 8 h followed by the process of incubation into 0.05 M ascorbic acid solution and thereafter multiple washes have been accomplished with a large pool of water so as to regenerate the nanomaterial. This procedure has been conducted for three-cycle every time to ensure the standard completion of the regeneration process. A minor change in the photocatalytic activity of the nanomaterials has been observed only after six cycles. Dhanalakshmi et al. [245] have carried out the photocatalytic degradation of Methylene Blue and Crystal Violet using Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst wherein it has been observed that the Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst has more stability and the photocatalytic activity has slightly decreased for the fifth cyclic run which might have resulted from the blockage of active sites by the degradation intermediates of organic pollutants and/or weight loss during the repeated filtration process whereby the catalyst has been separated from the reaction medium. In order to check the phase of the used photocatalyst, the XRD study has been carried out on Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst after five cycles run. They have observed that the intensity of the characteristic peaks and phase structure of the catalyst has no obvious change after the recycled photocatalysis such that no noticeable deviation could be found with respect to the fresh Ir/SnO2 nanocomposite. Furthermore, the used Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst morphology has also been investigated making use of TEM analysis. They have established that the fresh Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst shows the nanorods of spherical-shaped morphological structure. In contrast, the recycled Ir/SnO2 photocatalyst exhibits some aggregated morphology, but the shape of the nanoparticles has not changed, certifying high stability. He et al. [246] have carried out the photocatalytic degradation of Rhodamine B dye using SnO2-x/g-C3N4 and investigated the stability of the composite by undertaking a 10-run cycling test such that the obtained photodegradation efficiency of the composite shows no apparent decrease after the 10 reuse cycles. The authors have suggested that the SnO2-x/g-C3N4 photocatalyst can be reused completely and comprehensively for wastewater treatment. In addition to the high stability, the SnO2-x/g-C3N4 hybrid also exhibits the feasibility for the degradation of various organics. A further survey of literature that has been carried out related to the reuse of the SnO2-based photocatalyst has been summarized in Table 5. 10 Current challenges Although significant progress has been accomplished, many opportunities and challenges are still continued to remain such that further exploration of SnO2-based photocatalysts systems is required. Most of the research on SnO2-based photocatalysts is found to be focused on powder materials such that the synthesis of these powder materials in large quantities is very difficult and their respective recycling for real-time applications is also quite difficult. Even though most photocatalysts are non-toxic or less toxic, the consequences of a considerably large time of exposure to the environment and the probable toxicity of the intermediates in the reaction are not easily predictable. A comprehensive understanding of the charge transport process is very much essential so as to further improve the activity of SnO2-based photocatalysts. Although significant progress has been witnessed in the study of binary composites on this issue, the control over the handling of charge transfer in multi-component heterostructures still faces enormous challenges. Therefore, it is the need of the hour to conduct systematic research to reveal the potential photocatalytic enhancement so that the environment would be protected to a larger extent. At the same time, an in-depth and real-time study of the charge transport process in three or more component photocatalysts are required to enhance and advance this emerging research. A few precise and time-bound analytical techniques should be explored at the atomic and molecular level such that a deep understanding of the active sites, carrier transport paths, carrier life on the surfaces, interfaces and nanostructures of SnO2-based photocatalysts could become a reality. 11 Future challenges and prospects Heterogeneous photocatalysis is supposed to be viable to degrade recalcitrant organic pollutants in a much more effective manner than conventional approaches. In order to improve the technology's future viability, significant efforts will be required to overcome some challenges. First, a better understanding of the factors involved in the degradation mechanisms and how photocatalysts interact with other organic pollutants so as to bring about the desired outcome is still needed to be unearthed. Secondly, greater progress in nanostructure development may be possible. The photocatalysts, in most situations, determine the effectiveness of photocatalytic reactions. Despite the fact that existing approaches can synthesize effective photocatalysts (in terms of large surface area, small particle size, longer charge carrier life span, etc.), further innovative research oriented approach is the need of the hour in this field. There are other operational issues to solve issues such as photocatalyst loss and recovery during post-treatment, as well as photoactivity of recycled photocatalyst. In addition to that, more concerted effort is required in order to create and evaluate the relevant mathematical models that are applicable for photocatalytic operations/systems for water/wastewater treatment, in predicting quantum yield, kinetics, and the process's optimum condition. 12 Conclusion Photocatalysts made of SnO2 nanostructures have been authenticated to be a feasible alternative for the solar-driven photodegradation of persistent organic pollutants thereby these nanostructures could serve in a multifaceted scale to ensure a safer environment. These are to be promoted to a large extent because of their synthesis is inexpensive, non-toxicity, and ability to absorb a larger portion of the solar spectrum. It is clear out of the various methods of fabrication as described in this framework that tin oxide properties such as dimension, morphology, and particle size can be influenced by the nature of synthesis method undertaken. Solution-based approaches are preferred among the synthesis methods because they could provide a suitable environment for controlling the growth mechanisms of SnO2 nanostructures as proven experimentally by a well-controlled molar ratio of precursors. To improve the photoresponse of SnO2 nanostructures, many approaches have been tried such that consistent progress has been attained. The band gap energy of SnO2 is said to be a significant factor in terms of applications as it can influence the photoactivity. It may be concluded that metal/non-metal doping, coupling of SnO2 with other semiconductors, and photocatalyst in promoting the photodegradation applications. By modifying the band gap energy, controlling the recombination rate of e−–h+ pairs, improving charge separation efficiency, increasing the rate of production of hydroxyl radicals, maintaining smaller particle sizes contributing to high nanocarbon coupling could enhance the photocatalytic performance of SnO2 serving as a specific areas, and permitting a better dispersion in medium, the overall performances of the photoactivity can be improved. Future studies may be focussed on overcoming the missing links of SnO2 i.e. an in-depth study of the charge transport process in three or more component photocatalysts are required such that a few precise and time-bound analytical techniques could be explored at the atomic and molecular level. Moreover, a deep understanding is required of active sites, carrier transport paths, carrier life on the surfaces, interfaces and nanostructures of SnO2-based photocatalysts with which rarely utilized metals, non-metals, metal oxides, nano carbon components can be explored to synthesize tertiary, quaternary, etc. Henceforth, it is authenticated that SnO2-based nanocomposites and related composites may exhibit enhanced photocatalytic activity thereby the existing practical challenges could be eliminated by undertaking the optimum usage in such a way that delivering more efficient, reliable and stable performance can become a reality which will lead to the degradation of recalcitrant organic pollutants opening the flood gate of large scale applications. coredata.dc:description: Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) are proven to possess considerable resistance to environmental degradation such that they could not be entirely removed through the typical treatment processes. The consistent presence of these pollutants contributes to impending obnoxious health impacts that are concurrently inflicted on wildlife and human beings. In alignment of getting rid of these menaces, photocatalysis process has arrived as a tremendous remedy thereby the availability of clean and secure water could be ensured. In this review we focus on the potential progress in SnO2 nanostructures for enhancing the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, its current challenges and future perspectives.
